newsitem.title: JAPAN: U.S. Treasuries little changed in Tokyo trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries little changed in Tokyo trade.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries were little changed by Tokyo midday on Wednesday, with the absence of fresh incentives keeping activity quiet, traders said.
The two-day Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting ends later on Wednesday, but traders said the market was more interested in Thursday's U.S. employment data for June.
"People are not paying much heed to the FOMC as the Fed is widely expected to leave interest rates unchanged," said a Japanese bank trader.
Results of the FOMC meeting are due at around 1415 EDT/1815 GMT.
The September T-bond futures contract rose 2/32 to 111-24/32 from the previous close. It was moving in a range of 111-23/32 to 111-25/32.
The surprise announcement by the Bank of Thailand (BOT) on Wednesday morning to adopt a "managed float" system for the baht had no immediate impact on U.S. Treasuries, traders said.
Any flight-to-quality interest after a baht float is more likely to be directed towards the Japanese currency and yen bonds than the U.S. dollar and U.S. debt, the Japanese bank trader said.
